Award.AwardTitle: CBET: Upconversion Enhanced Visible Light Sensitization of Semiconductor Photocatalysts for Environmental Application

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1335934
Jaehong Kim
Yale University

Environmental application of semiconductor photocatalysts as a sustainable technology option has received significant attention over the past few decades with some notable commercial successes. But challenges still remain and are related to its relatively low efficiency of photosensitization by longer-wavelength, lower-energy light that is abundant in the solar spectrum. This project will develop a highly innovative approach of enhancing the visible light susceptibility of semiconductor-based photocatalytic process. This research aims at manipulating light to amplify its frequency via a unique photoluminescence process called upconversion (UC) based on a triplet-triplet annihilation (TTA) mechanism. Through the TTA-UC process, two photons of higher wavelength, which are otherwise wasted, are combined and converted to a single photon with lower wavelength; these upconverted photons are subsequently used to sensitize photocatalysts and to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) that effectively degrade pollutants and inactivate microorganisms in water. Researchers will employ a pair of organic sensitizers and acceptors that enable a highly efficient visible to visible or blue to UVA upconversion. Researchers will select various chromophore pairs, encapsulate them into microcapsules, and couple them with selected semiconductor photocatalysts. Various photoluminescence and photocatalytic experiments and instrumental analyses will be performed to quantitatively evaluate the properties of this new system including quantum yield, excitation and emission spectra, kinetics of energy transfer process (time-resolved spectra), and ROS production. The material synthesis and system development will be specifically targeted and tested for contaminant degradation and microbial inactivation in water as well as separation and recovery after use.

Ensuring access to inexpensive and clean sources of water is one of the greatest global challenges of this century. Advanced materials technology, such as the one developed in this project, offers opportunities to leapfrog over traditional infrastructure-intensive technologies to develop more sustainable approaches in both industrialized and developing countries, as long as cost efficacy is assured and unnecessary collateral impacts are avoided. This project has a great potential to develop solar-based technology that efficiently harvests lower-energy portions of the solar spectrum which is otherwise wasted in any existing photocatalyst-based processes. Researchers expect that UC/photocatalysts with improved solar energy utilization efficiency and capability for easy separation can be readily implemented in various environmental engineering practices including solar photocatalytic disinfection (e.g., implemented using a solar concentrator), advanced oxidation, and photocatalysis. The project aims at achieving this goal through effective integration the photophysics of upconversion, material synthesis, semiconductor photocatalysis, environmental micropollutant control, and disinfection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Environmental application of semiconductor photocatalysts as a sustainable technology option has received significant attentions over the past decade with some notable commercial successes. But challenges still remain and are related to its relatively low efficiency of photosensitization by longer-wavelength, lower-energy light that is abundant in the solar spectrum. This project focused on a highly innovative approach of enhancing the visible light susceptibility of semiconductor-based photocatalytic process. The project team aimed at manipulating light to amplify its frequency via a unique photoluminescence process called upconversion (UC) based on a triplet-triplet annihilation (TTA) mechanism. Through the TTA-UC process, two photons of higher wavelength, which are otherwise wasted, are combined and converted to a single photon with lower wavelength; these upconverted photons are subsequently used to sensitize photocatalysts and to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) that effectively degrade pollutants and inactivate microorganisms in water.

The project team synthesized nano-scale capsules made of silica shell and decorated them with cadmium sulfide semiconductor and graphene oxide nanodisc and demonstrated for the first time in literature that red light (low energy photons) can be converted to blue light (high energy photo) and ROS can be produced in the aqueous phase. Successful synthesis of silica nanocapsules enabled the researchers to explore other applications beyond initially-proposed water treatment including in vivo bioimaging. In particular, the researchers successfully synthesized and tested two different TTA-UC nanocapsuples that enabled dual-color in-vivo cancer cell imaging via red light irradiation (i.e., one type of cancer cell emitting blue color and another type of cancer cell emitting green color). We also applied similar TTA-UC nanocapsules to photochemically synthesize hydrogen peroxide, an oxidant widely used for advanced oxidation of water (i.e., degrading pollutants by highly reactive hydroxyl radical). We demonstrated for the first time in literature that red photons can be upconverted to produce hydrogen peroxide, which has not been possible in the past. The researchers further created a new way to achieving TTA-UC in an ambient condition based on rubbery polymer in the form of solid film. Using this film, the researchers successfully demonstrated photocatalytic destruction of volatile organic compound in air by indoor light, which is the first report in the literature in which TTA-UC chemistry is used for actual environmental pollutant degradation. The researchers also integrated this film to significantly improve the efficiency of light harvesting by dye-sensitized solar cell using a portion of solar spectrum that has never been converted to electricity.

Through this project, Yale University researchers made significant contributions to fundamental upconversion photophysics as well as actual application in diverse fields of engineering, ranging from environmental remediation application to bioimaging and solar cell applications, highlighting broader scientific impact of the project. Several researchers participated in this project including a few postdoctoral researchers (funded by other sources; two of them currently hold faculty position) and a female PhD student (funded by this project; expected to graduate in summer of 2018). The project also involved undergraduate students and high school students as a part of its education outreach. The project team published total eight papers in peer-reviewed journal articles (including one currently under review) and presented nine times at national and international conferences.
